<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i></h1>

<div id="contentSub"></div>

<div style="font-size:90%;">The cover of <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> volume 13, the first of Part 3 <a href="/wiki/Stardust_Crusaders" title="Stardust Crusaders">Stardust Crusaders</a>.</div>

<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background:#CCF; font-weight: bold;">Related media</td>

<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure_video_games" title="List of JoJo's Bizarre Adventure video games"><i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> video games</a></li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="noprint">
<td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background:#CCF; font-weight:bold"><span class="metadata"><a href="/wiki/File:Wikipe-tan_face.svg" class="image"><img alt="Portal icon" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Wikipe-tan_face.svg/16px-Wikipe-tan_face.svg.png" width="16" height="16" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Wikipe-tan_face.svg/24px-Wikipe-tan_face.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Wikipe-tan_face.svg/32px-Wikipe-tan_face.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="440" data-file-height="440" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Anime_and_Manga" title="Portal:Anime and Manga">Anime and Manga portal</a></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p><i><b>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</b></i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese</a>: <span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Ç∏„Éß„Ç∏„Éß„ÅÆÂ•áÂ¶ô„Å™ÂÜíÈô∫</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <a href="/wiki/Hepburn_romanization" title="Hepburn romanization">Hepburn</a>: <i>JoJo no Kimy≈ç na B≈çken</i><sup class="t_nihongo_help noprint"><a href="/wiki/Help:Installing_Japanese_character_sets" title="Help:Installing Japanese character sets"><span class="t_nihongo_icon" style="color: #00e; font: bold 80% sans-serif; text-decoration: none; padding: 0 .1em;">?</span></a></sup>)</span> is a Japanese <a href="/wiki/Manga" title="Manga">manga</a> series written and illustrated by <a href="/wiki/Hirohiko_Araki" title="Hirohiko Araki">Hirohiko Araki</a>. It was originally serialized in <i><a href="/wiki/Weekly_Sh%C5%8Dnen_Jump" title="Weekly Sh≈çnen Jump">Weekly Sh≈çnen Jump</a></i> from 1986 to 2004, before being transferred to the monthly <i><a href="/wiki/Seinen" title="Seinen" class="mw-redirect">seinen</a></i> magazine <i><a href="/wiki/Ultra_Jump" title="Ultra Jump">Ultra Jump</a></i> in 2005. The current story arc, <i><a href="/wiki/JoJolion" title="JoJolion">JoJolion</a></i>, started in 2011. <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> is currently <a href="/wiki/Shueisha" title="Shueisha">Shueisha</a>'s second <a href="/wiki/List_of_manga_series_by_volume_count" title="List of manga series by volume count">largest manga series</a> with its chapters collected into 115 tank≈çbon volumes and counting (only <i><a href="/wiki/Kochira_Katsushika-ku_Kameari_K%C5%8Den-mae_Hashutsujo" title="Kochira Katsushika-ku Kameari K≈çen-mae Hashutsujo">Kochira Katsushika-ku Kameari K≈çen-mae Hashutsujo</a></i>, with over 190, has more).</p>
<p>A six-volume <a href="/wiki/Original_video_animation" title="Original video animation">original video animation</a> adaptation of the later half of the series' third story arc was released from 1993 to 1994 by studio <a href="/wiki/A.P.P.P." title="A.P.P.P.">A.P.P.P.</a>, followed by another seven-volume series covering earlier parts of the arc from 2000 to 2002. A.P.P.P. also produced a theatrical film of the first arc in 2007. In 2012, an <a href="/wiki/Anime" title="Anime">anime</a> television series produced by <a href="/wiki/David_Production" title="David Production">David Production</a> began broadcast on <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Metropolitan_Television" title="Tokyo Metropolitan Television">Tokyo MX</a>, and covered the first two story arcs of the manga in 26 episodes. A second 48-episode season covering the third arc was broadcast in 2014 and 2015.</p>
<p>The <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> manga has over 95 million copies in print, making it one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_manga" title="List of best-selling manga">best-selling manga series</a> in history, and has spawned a large <a href="/wiki/Media_franchise" title="Media franchise">media franchise</a> that includes several novelizations and video games, action figures, a jewelry line, and even snack foods. From 2003 to 2005, Super Techno Arts released both OVA series in North America. <a href="/wiki/Viz_Media" title="Viz Media">Viz Media</a> released a translation of the third part of <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> in North America from 2005 to 2010, and began publishing English versions of the first two arcs in 2015.</p>
<p></p>

<p></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Plot">Plot</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Plot">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure_characters" title="List of JoJo's Bizarre Adventure characters">List of JoJo's Bizarre Adventure characters</a></div>
<p><i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> tells the story of the Joestar family, a family whose various members discover they are destined to take down supernatural foes using unique powers that they find they possess. The manga is split up into 8 unique parts, each following the story of one member of the Joestar family, who inevitably has a name that can be abbreviated to the titular "JoJo". The first six parts of the series take place within a single continuity, while parts 7 and 8 take place in an alternate continuity.</p>
<dl>
<dt>Part 1 <i><a href="/wiki/Phantom_Blood" title="Phantom Blood">Phantom Blood</a></i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Éï„Ç°„É≥„Éà„É†„Éñ„É©„ÉÉ„Éâ</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Fantomu Buraddo</i>)</span></dt>
<dd><i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> volumes 1 to 5. In 1880s <a href="/wiki/Great_Britain" title="Great Britain">Great Britain</a>, the young Jonathan Joestar meets his new adopted brother <a href="/wiki/Dio_Brando" title="Dio Brando">Dio Brando</a>, who only wants to usurp Jonathan as heir to the Joestar family. However, his attempts are thwarted and he resorts to using an ancient Stone Mask which transforms him into a vampire. Jonathan, with Italian Ripple master Will A. Zeppeli and former street thug Robert E.O. Speedwagon at his side, must now find a way to stop Dio using his newly found affinity for the Ripple martial arts now that Dio's sights are set on nothing less than world domination.</dd>
<dt>Part 2 <i><a href="/wiki/Battle_Tendency" title="Battle Tendency">Battle Tendency</a></i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Êà¶ÈóòÊΩÆÊµÅ</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Sent≈ç Ch≈çry≈´</i>)</span></dt>
<dd><i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> volumes 5 to 12. In <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a> in 1938, Joseph Joestar, grandson of Jonathan, who has a natural affinity for the Ripple, becomes entangled in his grandfather's destiny when the Pillar Men, supernatural beings of impossible power, awaken after failed experiments by Nazi German special forces. Joseph ultimately teams up with Caesar Zeppeli, Will's grandson, and Caesar's teacher Lisa Lisa, a woman mysteriously tied to Joseph, to stop the Pillar Men from obtaining a mystical artifact in Lisa Lisa's possession that will grant them complete immortality and bring about the end of the world at their hands, so long as Joseph can master the Ripple to beat the Pillar Men in a rematch for the antidotes to poisons they implanted in his body.</dd>
<dt>Part 3 <i><a href="/wiki/Stardust_Crusaders" title="Stardust Crusaders">Stardust Crusaders</a></i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Çπ„Çø„Éº„ÉÄ„Çπ„Éà„ÇØ„É´„Çª„Ç§„ÉÄ„Éº„Çπ</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>SutƒÅdasuto KuruseidƒÅsu</i>)</span></dt>
<dd><i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> volumes 12 to 28. In 1989, Jotaro Kujo, a Japanese high school student, places himself in jail because he believes he is possessed by an evil spirit. His mother Holly calls on her father Joseph Joestar to talk sense into Jotaro, and with the help of his ally the Egyptian fortune teller Mohammed Avdol, reveals that Jotaro has in fact developed a supernatural ability known as a Stand that has run through the family due to the revival of their ancestor's foe Dio. After thwarting an assassination attempt by transfer student Noriaki Kakyoin who is under Dio's thrall, Jotaro and Joseph discover that Holly is dying from her own Stand. Jotaro resolves to hunt down Dio, and Joseph leads him, Avdol, and Kakyoin to Egypt, using their Stands to battle more Stand-wielding assassins along the way, gaining allies in the French swordsman Jean Pierre Polnareff who wishes to avenge the death of his sister, and the stray dog Iggy, before 50 days elapse and Holly dies.</dd>
<dt>Part 4 <i><a href="/wiki/Diamond_Is_Unbreakable" title="Diamond Is Unbreakable">Diamond Is Unbreakable</a></i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„ÉÄ„Ç§„É§„É¢„É≥„Éâ„ÅØÁ†ï„Åë„Å™„ÅÑ</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Daiyamondo wa Kudakenai</i>)</span></dt>
<dd><i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> volumes 29 to 47. In the fictional Japanese town of Morioh in 1999, Jotaro arrives to reveal to Josuke Higashikata (the kanji <span lang="ja">Âä©</span> in his name is read in the <i><a href="/wiki/On%27yomi" title="On'yomi" class="mw-redirect">on'yomi</a></i> form as <i>jo</i>) that he is the illegitimate son of Joseph Joestar and to warn him that Morioh is beginning to be filled with Stand users due to a mystical Bow and Arrow that bestows Stands on those struck by the arrowheads. After Josuke takes revenge on a Stand user who killed his grandfather, he agrees to help Jotaro hunt down the holder of the Bow and Arrow, gaining allies in Josuke's friend Koichi Hirose, who is hit by the arrow, Okuyasu Nijimura, whose brother was using the Arrow until it was stolen from him, the famous manga artist Rohan Kishibe, and even his estranged father Joseph Joestar. Along the way, the group deals with the various new Stand users throughout Morioh, including several of Josuke, Koichi, and Okuyasu's classmates, until the death of one of their friends leads to the discovery that one of the new Stand users is the notorious serial killer Yoshikage Kira.</dd>
<dt>Parte 5 <i><a href="/wiki/Vento_Aureo" title="Vento Aureo">Vento Aureo</a></i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">ÈªÑÈáë„ÅÆÈ¢®</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>≈ågon no Kaze</i>)</span></dt>
<dd><i>Le Bizzarre Avventure di GioGio</i> volumes 47 to 63. In 2001, Koichi Hirose is sent by Jotaro to <a href="/wiki/Naples" title="Naples">Naples</a> to investigate Giorno Giovanna, whom Jotaro has discovered is Dio's son fathered before his defeat in Cairo 12 years earlier, to see if the boy has a Stand and if he is evil. Koichi ultimately discovers the boy's Stand and his pure goals for reforming the mafia from the inside out, and Jotaro lets him live his life. Giorno ultimately joins a squad of Passione, a Stand-using mafia, led by Bruno Bucciarati, who leads Giorno, Leone Abbacchio, Guido Mista, Narancia Ghirga, and Pannacotta Fugo on a mission to <a href="/wiki/Capri" title="Capri">Capri</a> to retrieve his former superior's riches, being attacked by rival mafioso along the way, and then are tasked by Passione's boss to escort his daughter Trish Una throughout Italy and protect her from others in the gang who wish to use her to find out his identity.</dd>
<dt>Part 6 <i><a href="/wiki/Stone_Ocean" title="Stone Ocean">Stone Ocean</a></i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Çπ„Éà„Éº„É≥„Ç™„Éº„Ç∑„É£„É≥</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Sut≈çn ≈åshan</i>)</span></dt>
<dd><i>Stone Ocean</i> volumes 1 to 17 (<i>JoJo</i> volumes 64 to 80). In 2011 near <a href="/wiki/Port_St._Lucie,_Florida" title="Port St. Lucie, Florida">Port St. Lucie, Florida</a>, Jolyne Cujoh is arrested and sent to the Green Dolphin St. Prison for murder. Her estranged father Jotaro visits her and reveals that she has been set up in order for one of Dio's disciples to kill her within the prison. After revealing that a gift he gave her has awoken her latent Stand powers to protect her, he is attacked, and his Stand is stolen from him by the prison chaplain Enrico Pucci, Dio's disciple. Jolyne works with fellow inmate Ermes Costello, who has also had a Stand awoken in her, to retrieve her father's Stand, gaining allies in the boy Emporio Alni√±o, other inmates Narciso Anasui and Weather Report, and the sentient Stand-using plankton Foo Fighters to save her father and stop Pucci before he can use his Stand to recreate the universe in Dio's image.</dd>
<dt>Part 7 <i><a href="/wiki/Steel_Ball_Run" title="Steel Ball Run">Steel Ball Run</a></i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Çπ„ÉÜ„Ç£„Éº„É´„Éª„Éú„Éº„É´„Éª„É©„É≥</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Sutƒ´ru B≈çru Ran</i>)</span></dt>
<dd><i>Steel Ball Run</i> volumes 1 to 24 (<i>JoJo</i> volumes 81 to 104). In an alternate timeline in 1890, Gyro Zeppeli travels to the United States to take part in a cross-country horse race known as the Steel Ball Run. His skill in a mystical martial art known as the Rotation, which he controls with steel balls, garners the interest of former jockey turned paraplegic Johnny Joestar, particularly after a Rotation-infused ball briefly restores Johnny's ability to walk. Johnny travels with Gyro on the race to learn the Rotation from him in hopes he can be cured, but they soon discover that the race is a ploy set up by Funny Valentine, the President of the United States, to search the country for the scattered parts of a holy corpse that imbue their holders with a Stand, so the President can use the entire corpse to his own patriotic ends, even if it means the disruption of other dimensions with his Stand's ability. Gyro and Johnny work together, along with fellow racers Mountain Tim and Hot Pants and race organizer Stephen Steel and his wife Lucy, to stop the President from his plans, as they threaten the very world, all while dealing with Valentine's hired assassins in the race, including the charismatic racer Diego Brando.</dd>
<dt>Part 8 <i><a href="/wiki/JoJolion" title="JoJolion">JoJolion</a></i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Ç∏„Éß„Ç∏„Éß„É™„Ç™„É≥</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Jojorion</i>)</span></dt>
<dd><i>JoJolion</i> is currently being published, beginning with the 105th overall volume of <i>JoJo</i>. In 2012, in the same continuity as <i>Steel Ball Run</i>, the town of Morioh has been devastated by the <a href="/wiki/2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami" title="2011 T≈çhoku earthquake and tsunami">2011 T≈çhoku earthquake and tsunami</a>, which has caused mysterious faults colloquially known as the "Wall Eyes" to appear in town. Local college student Yasuho Hirose is near one of the Wall Eyes when she discovers a young man buried in the rubble, and a strange bite mark on him. She nicknames him "Josuke", as he cannot remember his own name, and after following a lead that he may be "Yoshikage Kira", an attack by a Stand user leads them to find the real Yoshikage Kira's corpse. Josuke is put in the care of the Higashikata family, whose patriarch Norisuke IV seems to know more about Josuke than he initially lets on, but Josuke himself discovers that the Higashikata family and Yoshikage Kira's family are linked due to Johnny Joestar's marriage to Rina Higashikata in the late 19th century. Josuke and Yasuho ultimately discover that Josuke is in fact Yoshikage Kira, mysteriously fused with another person, and Yoshikage Kira possessed the knowledge to cure a curse that has plagued the Higashikata family for centuries. Norisuke IV wants that knowledge back to save his grandchild from the same fate he and his family has suffered, but a mysterious race of rock men and Norisuke IV's own son Jobin seem to be conspiring against them to both prevent Josuke from regaining his memories and from lifting the curse on the Higashikata family.</dd>
</dl>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Supernatural_powers">Supernatural powers</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Supernatural powers">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The first supernatural item introduced in Part 1 <i><a href="/wiki/Phantom_Blood" title="Phantom Blood">Phantom Blood</a></i> is the Stone Mask <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Áü≥‰ªÆÈù¢</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Ishikamen</i>)</span>, an artifact discovered in Aztec ruins that seems to react with blood. It is soon revealed that when it is worn by someone and blood is spilled on it, the Stone Mask produces spikes that drive themselves into the wearer's skull, hitting <a href="/wiki/Accupuncture" title="Accupuncture" class="mw-redirect">accupuncture</a> points that transforms them into an immortal <a href="/wiki/Vampire" title="Vampire">Vampire</a> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Âê∏Ë°ÄÈ¨º</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Ky≈´ketsuki</i>)</span>. These Vampires drain people of their blood through their fangs or their pointed fingernails, and seemingly have full control of their bodies, able to heal from most injuries and even make it so they can combine other creatures into abominations, such as Dio Brando's tendency to put human heads on animal bodies. A Vampire can only be killed by destroying the head, as the vampirism is held in the brain, or by exposure to natural sunlight or ultraviolet rays. The Ripple <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Ê≥¢Á¥ã</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Hamon</i>)</span> is introduced as a martial arts technique that allows the user to focus bodily energy into other kinds of energy via proper breathing, and it is effective in combating Vampires as experienced Ripple users can emulate sunlight. Such energy is also useful in combating the Vampires' Zombies <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Â±çÁîü‰∫∫Ôºà„Çæ„É≥„ÉìÔºâ</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Zonbi</i>, also referred to as "Undead" <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">‰∫°ËÄÖÔºà„Ç¢„É≥„Éá„ÉÉ„ÉâÔºâ</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Andeddo</i>)</span>)</span>, which Vampires can create by imparting some of their vampiric essence into the once living or even the long deceased.</p>
<p>Part 2 <i><a href="/wiki/Battle_Tendency" title="Battle Tendency">Battle Tendency</a></i> introduces the Pillar Men <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Êü±„ÅÆÁî∑</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Hashira no Otoko</i>)</span>, an ancient race of apex predators and progenitors to the Vampires as one of their members created the Stone Masks in an attempt to find a way to bypass their species' weakness to sunlight so they may rule Earth. When they are exposed to sunlight, they turn to stone, thus making them susceptible to the energies of the Ripple. Their remaining members, as the rest were slaughtered for trying to prevent them from raising to power, seek out the Red Stone of Aja <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Ç®„Ç§„Ç∏„É£„ÅÆËµ§Áü≥</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Eija no Sekiseki</i>)</span>, a naturally occurring gem that amplifies light into nearly laser precision, as its power is able to perfect the transformation into a truly immortal being with control over all life's forces. However, only a flawless stone can produce these results, and it is this reason that the Ripple users protect the flawless Super Aja so it can never fall into the hands of the Pillar Men.</p>
<p>Part 3 <i><a href="/wiki/Stardust_Crusaders" title="Stardust Crusaders">Stardust Crusaders</a></i> begins by introducing the supernatural power of Stands <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Çπ„Çø„É≥„Éâ</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Sutando</i>)</span>, so named because the semi-physical manifestation of the user's psychic powers resembles a spiritual familiar standing next to them. When first presented, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Joestar" title="Joseph Joestar" class="mw-redirect">Joseph Joestar</a> refers to it as a "Ghostly Ripple" <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">ÂπΩÊ≥¢Á¥ãÔºà„Çπ„Çø„É≥„ÉâÔºâ</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Sutando</i>, but without <a href="/wiki/Furigana" title="Furigana">furigana</a> it would be pronounced <i>y≈´ hamon</i>)</span>; it could conjecturally be said to be a semi-physical manifestation of one's Ripple powers. The exact requirements for a person to obtain a Stand are unclear, although the series hints that it can be linked to bloodline, rigorous spiritual and/or Ripple training, and/or exceptionally strong willpower and/or desire. A Stand may never manifest itself in one's life until it is amplified by certain conditions or factors. However, not everyone able to manifest a Stand has the ability to control it; despite her father Joseph Joestar and her son <a href="/wiki/Jotaro_Kujo" title="Jotaro Kujo" class="mw-redirect">Jotaro Kujo</a> being powerful Stand users, Holly Kujo, due to her lack of physical strength, resolve, and her peaceful nature, is brought to the brink of death by her Stand, which saps away her life in an attempt to manifest itself. Generally, destroying a Stand will result in the death of its user. Likewise, if the Stand user is incapacitated, the Stand will no longer be a threat. There are instances of automatic Stands that act on the user's subconscious level until recognized, and there are rare cases of Stands that exist after the user's death, becoming nigh unstoppable and unpredictable without anyone controlling it. Some Stands appear to have a separate and autonomous personality from their users, able to act on their own to protect them, or speak to them.</p>
<p>A Stand can also be brought forth after one is pierced by the Bow and Arrow <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Âºì„Å®Áü¢</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Yumi to Ya</i>)</span>, forged from a mysterious meteorite that made its way to Earth after being drawn in by the spiritual powers of the planet's inhabitants. The Bow and Arrow was hinted at in Part 3 and retroactively introduced in Part 4 <i><a href="/wiki/Diamond_Is_Unbreakable" title="Diamond Is Unbreakable">Diamond Is Unbreakable</a></i>; they were expanded upon in Part 5 <i><a href="/wiki/Vento_Aureo" title="Vento Aureo">Vento Aureo</a></i> as being discovered on an archaeological dig by the villain Diavolo, who sold five Arrows to Enya the Hag of Part 3 and kept one for himself. However, using the Arrows is often a gamble, as it could easily kill an unqualified person, and there is no apparent way to know if a person is qualified ahead of time; the Arrows do, however, tend to seek out qualified people on their own if there is someone to guide them. The Arrows also have the ability to make a Stand even more powerful if its user is hit with the Arrow; such an event causes the Stand of Part 4's Yoshikage Kira to develop a near unstoppable ability. However, if a Stand is struck by an Arrow, the Stand's powers are increased to such a limitless extent that it becomes a brand new "Requiem" <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">ÈéÆÈ≠ÇÊ≠åÔºà„É¨„ÇØ„Ç§„Ç®„É†Ôºâ</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Rekuiemu</i>)</span> Stand, achieving limitless powers.</p>
<p>In Part 6, there are examples of a single person possessing two Stands because of the ability of an extraordinary Stand. <a href="/wiki/Enrico_Pucci" title="Enrico Pucci" class="mw-redirect">Enrico Pucci</a> of Part 6 <i><a href="/wiki/Stone_Ocean" title="Stone Ocean">Stone Ocean</a></i> is able to produce artificial Stand users with his own, by stealing others' Stands and transforming them into Discs <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Éá„Ç£„Çπ„ÇØ</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Disuku</i>)</span> and then "inserting" them into regular people. It is unclear as to whether or not these artificial Stand users were capable of having Stands of their own, but Enrico does claim that only certain individuals are qualified to have Stand Discs inserted. Part 6 also features the Bones of DIO <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">DIO„ÅÆÈ™®</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>DIO no Hone</i>)</span> which are instrumental in Pucci's Way to Heaven <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Â§©ÂõΩ„Å∏Ë°å„ÅèÊñπÊ≥ï</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Tengoku e Iku H≈çh≈ç</i>)</span>. It first absorbs the souls of 36 sinners and transforms into the strange Green Baby, and grants Pucci a new and more powerful Stand that ultimately leads to his Way to Heaven and an even more powerful time and reality warping Stand. His powers and his ultimate defeat creates a new universe that rewrites all of the rules of reality.</p>
<p>Part 7 <i><a href="/wiki/Steel_Ball_Run" title="Steel Ball Run">Steel Ball Run</a></i> introduces the Rotation <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">ÂõûËª¢</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Kaiten</i>)</span>, a technique that incorporates the <a href="/wiki/Golden_ratio" title="Golden ratio">golden ratio</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Golden_rectangle" title="Golden rectangle">golden rectangle</a> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">ÈªÑÈáëÈï∑ÊñπÂΩ¢</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>≈çgon ch≈çh≈çkei</i>)</span> into a means of manipulating the <a href="/wiki/Magnus_effect" title="Magnus effect">Magnus effect</a> to the user's benefit. It is used by the Neapolitan Zeppeli family as physicians to treat patients, but its true power lies in its destructive effects which the Zeppelis also use in their secret role as executioners. Gyro Zeppeli in particular uses specially made Steel Balls <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">ÈâÑÁêÉ</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Tekky≈´</i>)</span> to impart the Rotation, with successful strikes causing the target's skin and muscles to contort and twist with the Rotation's energies. Johnny Joestar later learns to incorporate the Rotation through the powers of his Stand, increasing its power exponentially through new lessons and discoveries. An alternate version of the Rotation used by the Neapolitan Royal Guard uses specially made Steel Balls called Wrecking Balls <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„É¨„ÉÉ„Ç≠„É≥„Ç∞„Éª„Éú„Éº„É´ÔºàÂ£ä„Çå„ÇÜ„ÅèÈâÑÁêÉÔºâ</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Rekkingu B≈çru (Kowareyuku Tekky≈´)</i>)</span>, which have smaller Satellite <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Ë°õÊòü</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Eisei</i>)</span> balls embedded in them that are able to impart the Rotation and may cause temporary <a href="/wiki/Hemispatial_neglect" title="Hemispatial neglect">hemispatial neglect</a> if successfully struck. The Rotation's most powerful form incorporates the golden rectangle perfectly into the Golden Rotation <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">ÈªÑÈáë„ÅÆÂõûËª¢</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>≈ågon no Kaiten</i>)</span>, producing a Rotation that is able to transcend dimensional walls and even produce a Stand manifestation. Such an effect can only be attained after achieving a certain speed on horseback and using the horse to extend control over the golden rectangle. Also introduced in Part 7 is the Saint's Corpse <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">ËÅñ‰∫∫„ÅÆÈÅ∫‰Ωì</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Seijin no Itai</i>)</span>, body parts of a deceased holy man (hinted to be <a href="/wiki/Jesus_Christ" title="Jesus Christ" class="mw-redirect">Jesus Christ</a>) that imbue the user with a Stand if the body part is fused with the user. If the user loses the Corpse part, they lose their Stand, although it may fuse to such an extent that the Stand becomes a permanent part of the person. There is a legend within the fiction that if someone were to gather all of the Corpse's parts, he would be able to rule the world. Also shown is the Devil's Palm <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">ÊÇ™È≠î„ÅÆÊâã„ÅÆ„Å≤„Çâ</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Akuma no Tenohira</i>)</span>, a geographic place where the Saint died that seems to move on its own accord and tests those who come across it. If the person survives, he or she is granted a Stand.</p>
<p>Part 8 <i><a href="/wiki/JoJolion" title="JoJolion">JoJolion</a></i> introduces another method of obtaining a Stand, interaction with the Wall Eyes <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Â£Å„ÅÆÁõÆ</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Kabe no Me</i>)</span>, strange <a href="/wiki/Fault_(geology)" title="Fault (geology)">fault</a>-like structures that have risen from the ground following the <a href="/wiki/2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami" title="2011 T≈çhoku earthquake and tsunami">2011 T≈çhoku earthquake and tsunami</a>. They disrupt all forms of transportation, communication, and utilities, but all users of Stands have come in contact with the Wall Eyes at some point. Three (Josuke Higashikata, Yasuho Hirose, and Joshu Higashikata) have all received painful bite marks from their proximity to the Wall Eyes, and the three of them have all developed Stands. Other users of Stands have either fallen into the faults (as with Daiya Higashikata) or grown up in an area where the Wall Eye has erupted later in their life (Ojiro Sasame). A race of Stand-using Rock People <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Â≤©‰∫∫Èñì</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Iwa Ningen</i>)</span> also appears in <i>JoJolion</i>. These humans seem to innately possess the ability to turn their body into stone and enter a state of suspended animation. They can remain in this state so long as they still have air in their lungs, even if they are submerged in water, otherwise they will crumble away and die. As a rock, they are impervious to pain from even a Stand-empowered barrage of punches, but damage to their rock body will cause them to bleed. Within Morioh, they appear to have assumed the identities of missing children and have taken names from nearby mountain ranges.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Development">Development</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Development">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Paul_Gauguin_106.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Paul_Gauguin_106.jpg/220px-Paul_Gauguin_106.jpg" width="220" height="175" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Paul_Gauguin_106.jpg/330px-Paul_Gauguin_106.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Paul_Gauguin_106.jpg/440px-Paul_Gauguin_106.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3176" data-file-height="2527" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Paul_Gauguin_106.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Araki is inspired by western art, such as this piece by <a href="/wiki/Paul_Gauguin" title="Paul Gauguin">Paul Gauguin</a> which inspired him to use unusual colors in his own art.<sup id="cite_ref-comipress_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-comipress-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>For <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i>, Araki wanted to use a classical method as a base and then introduce modern elements in the singular. As an example, he often draws in a realistic style but then colors completely impossible colors. Araki has been aiming to draw real spirits in <i>JoJo</i> resulting in him going to the Kappa River in <a href="/wiki/T%C5%8Dno,_Iwate" title="T≈çno, Iwate">T≈çno, Iwate</a>, to get a better understanding of the concept.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> The series' colors are based on calculations. As a result, the colors in the manga are often inconsistent. Araki claims getting inspiration from the art of the 1980s, shading techniques in Western art, and classical paintings. He also claims mystery is the central theme of the manga, as he was fascinated by it as a child. Furthermore, Araki wanted to explore superpowers and energy in <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> resulting into various concepts such as the Ripple and the Stands. For <i>Stardust Crusaders</i> in particular, Araki was influenced by role-playing games in designing the characters' skills.<sup id="cite_ref-comipress_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-comipress-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Araki uses unique <a href="/wiki/Onomatopoeia" title="Onomatopoeia">onomatopoeia</a> and poses in the series, which he attributes to his love for <a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music" title="Heavy metal music">heavy metal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Horror_film" title="Horror film">horror films</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The poses, which are known in Japan as <i>JoJo-dachi</i> <span style="font-weight:normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Ç∏„Éß„Ç∏„ÉßÁ´ã„Å°</span><span class="t_nihongo_help"><sup><a href="/wiki/Help:Installing_Japanese_character_sets" title="Help:Installing Japanese character sets"><span style="color:#00e; font:bold 80% sans-serif; text-decoration:none; padding:0 .1em;">?</span></a></sup></span>, lit. "JoJo standing")</span>, are iconic on his book covers and panels, and were inspired by Araki's trip to Italy in his 20s and his studies of <a href="/wiki/Michelangelo" title="Michelangelo">Michelangelo</a>'s sculptures.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> The poses are so popular that fans often reenact them in homage to <i>JoJo</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Toole_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Toole-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> A reporter for <i>Rocket News</i> attempted to shop at the special 25th anniversary <i>JoJo</i>-themed <a href="/wiki/Lawson_(store)" title="Lawson (store)">Lawson</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sendai" title="Sendai">Sendai</a> in a <i>JoJo-dachi</i> in 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> and in 2014, singer <a href="/wiki/Shoko_Nakagawa" title="Shoko Nakagawa">Shoko Nakagawa</a> remarked that she accidentally broke her <a href="/wiki/Coccyx" title="Coccyx">coccyx</a> after performing a <i>JoJo-dachi</i> during a concert in <a href="/wiki/Nagoya" title="Nagoya">Nagoya</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The characters had no models with the exception of Jotaro Kujo who was based on <a href="/wiki/Clint_Eastwood" title="Clint Eastwood">Clint Eastwood</a>. For every part, Araki stated that he wanted to try a different type of main character. For example, whereas Part 1's Jonathan Joestar was a serious person, Part 2's Joseph Joestar was a rude person.<sup id="cite_ref-lecture_3_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lecture_3-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> Although their personalities are different, the two share a physical resemblance in order to have some continuity because it was unheard of at the time for a main character to die in <i>Weekly Sh≈çnen Jump</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> Araki's consistent focus on the Joestar family was intended to give a feeling of pride as well as due to the wonder and mystery there is on the lineage. When Part 3 ended, he wondered whether there should be a Part 4 due to the natural ending <i>Stardust Crusaders</i> had.<sup id="cite_ref-lecture_3_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lecture_3-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> For Part 6, Araki wrote a female protagonist for the first time which he found complicated, but he also found it interesting due to the humanity she could possess.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Media">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Manga">Manga</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Manga">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure_volumes" title="List of JoJo's Bizarre Adventure volumes">List of JoJo's Bizarre Adventure volumes</a></div>
<p>Written and illustrated by <a href="/wiki/Hirohiko_Araki" title="Hirohiko Araki">Hirohiko Araki</a>, <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> began serialization in <i><a href="/wiki/Weekly_Sh%C5%8Dnen_Jump" title="Weekly Sh≈çnen Jump">Weekly Sh≈çnen Jump</a></i> in its combined issue #1-2 of 1987, which was released on December 2, 1986. The chapters are collected and published into <a href="/wiki/Tank%C5%8Dbon" title="Tank≈çbon">tank≈çbon</a> volumes by <a href="/wiki/Shueisha" title="Shueisha">Shueisha</a>, with the first released on August 10, 1987.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> The series is broken into arcs or parts, each of which stars a descendant of the Joestar family. During Part 5, which takes place in Italy, the series' title was written in Italian as <i>Le Bizzarre Avventure di GioGio</i>. After volume 63, each parts' tank≈çbon have started the number count back at one; see <i><a href="/wiki/Stone_Ocean" title="Stone Ocean">Stone Ocean</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Steel_Ball_Run" title="Steel Ball Run">Steel Ball Run</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/JoJolion" title="JoJolion">JoJolion</a></i>. The series was switched to the magazine <i><a href="/wiki/Ultra_Jump" title="Ultra Jump">Ultra Jump</a></i> in 2004, during <i>Steel Ball Run</i>, with the chapters published monthly. <i>JoJolion</i>, the current arc, began on May 19, 2011. In 2012, the first three Parts of the series were digitally colored and released as digital downloads for <a href="/wiki/Smartphone" title="Smartphone">smartphones</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tablet_computer" title="Tablet computer">tablet computers</a>. A physical version of this re-release was collected under the title <i>JoJonium</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Ç∏„Éß„Ç∏„Éß„Éã„Ç¶„É†</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Jojoniumu</i>)</span> beginning December 4, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In the early 1990s <a href="/wiki/Viz_Media" title="Viz Media">Viz Media</a> had planned to release an English-language version of <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> in North America as "<i>The Strange Adventures of Jojo</i>", evident by an ad in their newsletter at the time, <i>Viz-In</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-1000manga_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1000manga-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> It is suspected the plans were canned after <i><a href="/wiki/Baoh" title="Baoh">Baoh</a></i>, another series by Hirohiko Araki, sold poorly. The series was brought up again for talks in 2002, for release as individual monthly chapters.<sup id="cite_ref-1000manga_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1000manga-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> However, by this time, that publication format for manga was on its way-out in North America.</p>
<p><i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> finally received a North American release in 2005, in the graphic novel format, similar to its Japanese <i>tank≈çbon</i>. However, it is only of the series' third part, <a href="/wiki/Stardust_Crusaders" title="Stardust Crusaders">Stardust Crusaders</a>, which is the most popular and well-known.<sup id="cite_ref-1000manga_15-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1000manga-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> Originally published bimonthly, the volumes were later reduced to a quarterly release. The first volume was released on November 8, 2005 and the last on December 7, 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> Viz's release changed the names of several characters due to copyright concerns and included some censorship, scenes of animal violence were redrawn by Araki himself.<sup id="cite_ref-1000manga_15-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1000manga-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> has also seen domestic releases in <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a> by <a href="/wiki/Star_Comics_(Italy)" title="Star Comics (Italy)">Star Comics</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup> in France by J'ai Lu and <a href="/wiki/Tonkam" title="Tonkam">Tonkam</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> by Da Ran Culture Enterprise and <a href="/wiki/Tong_Li_Publishing" title="Tong Li Publishing">Tong Li Publishing</a>, and in <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a> by <a href="/wiki/Comics_House" title="Comics House" class="mw-redirect">Comics House</a>.</p>
<p>In 2013, Viz revealed that they planned to release the third part digitally and expressed interest in further material of the series, however, they explained the difficulties due to the numerous references to real-life musicians and fashion designers.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> Viz Media began publishing the <i>JoJonium</i> edition of <i>Phantom Blood</i> digitally in September 2014, with a three-volume hardcover print edition that includes color pages following throughout 2015. At <a href="/wiki/Anime_Expo" title="Anime Expo">Anime Expo</a> on July 3, 2014, they announced they had also licensed part 2 <i>Battle Tendency</i>, which they began publishing digitally in March 2015 and in print in November 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Spin-offs">Spin-offs</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Spin-offs">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Araki has also drawn several <a href="/wiki/Spin-off_(media)" title="Spin-off (media)">spin-offs</a> of <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i>. The first being <i>Thus Spoke Kishibe Rohan. Episode 16: At a Confessional</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Â≤∏Ëæ∫Èú≤‰º¥„ÅØÂãï„Åã„Å™„ÅÑ ~„Ç®„Éî„ÇΩ„Éº„Éâ16:Êá∫ÊÇîÂÆ§~</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Kishibe Rohan wa Ugokanai Epis≈çdo Shikkusutƒ´n: Zangeshitsu</i>)</span> published in <i>Weekly Sh≈çnen Jump</i> in 1997, which stars <a href="/wiki/Rohan_Kishibe" title="Rohan Kishibe" class="mw-redirect">Rohan Kishibe</a> from Part 4. <i>Deadman's Questions</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Éá„ÉÉ„Éâ„Éû„É≥„Ç∫Q</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Deddomanzu Kuesuchonzu</i>)</span> is a three chapter story starring <a href="/wiki/Yoshikage_Kira" title="Yoshikage Kira" class="mw-redirect">Yoshikage Kira</a> from Part 4 and was published in the magazine <i>Allman</i> in 1999. Both of these were later collected in Araki's 1999 <i>Under Execution, Under Jailbreak</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Ê≠ªÂàëÂü∑Ë°å‰∏≠ËÑ±ÁçÑÈÄ≤Ë°å‰∏≠</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Shikei Shikk≈çch≈´ Datsugoku Shink≈çch≈´</i>)</span> collection of <a href="/wiki/One-shot_(comics)" title="One-shot (comics)">one-shots</a>. <i>Oingo Boingo Brothers Adventure</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Ç™„Ç§„É≥„Ç¥„Å®„Éú„Ç§„É≥„Ç¥ÂÖÑÂºüÂ§ßÂÜíÈô∫</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Oingo to Boingo Ky≈çdai Daib≈çken</i>)</span> was released in October 2002,<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup> features the titular characters originally from Part 3 and is drawn in the same art style as Boingo's Stand, which is a fortune-telling comic book. Continuing the series starring Rohan, <i>Thus Spoke Rohan Kishibe -Mutsu-kabe Hill-</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Â≤∏Ëæ∫Èú≤‰º¥„ÅØÂãï„Åã„Å™„ÅÑ -ÂÖ≠Â£ÅÂùÇ-</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Kishibe Rohan wa Ugokanai -Mutsukabezaka-</i>)</span> was published in <i><a href="/wiki/Jump_Square" title="Jump Square">Jump SQ</a></i> in 2007. <i>Thus Spoke Rohan Kishibe ~Episode 5: Millionaire Village~</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Â≤∏Ëæ∫Èú≤‰º¥„ÅØÂãï„Åã„Å™„ÅÑ ÔΩû„Ç®„Éî„ÇΩ„Éº„Éâ5:ÂØåË±™ÊùëÔΩû</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Kishibe Rohan wa Ugokanai ~Epis≈çdo Faibu: Fug≈çmura~</i>)</span> was published in the October 6, 2012 issue of <i>Weekly Sh≈çnen Jump</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Episode5_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Episode5-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Thus Spoke Rohan Kishibe ~Episode 6: Poaching Seashore~</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Â≤∏Ëæ∫Èú≤‰º¥„ÅØÂãï„Åã„Å™„ÅÑ ÔΩû„Ç®„Éî„ÇΩ„Éº„Éâ6 ÂØÜÊºÅÊµ∑Â≤∏ÔΩû</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Kishibe Rohan wa Ugokanai ~Epis≈çdo Shikkusu: Mitsury≈ç Kaigan~</i>)</span> was published in <i>Weekly Sh≈çnen Jump</i> on October 12, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> The newest part of the series <i>Thus Spoke Rohan Kishibe Episode #07 Monday - Sun Shower</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Â≤∏Ëæ∫Èú≤‰º¥„ÅØÂãï„Åã„Å™„ÅÑ „Ç®„Éî„ÇΩ„Éº„Éâ#07 ÊúàÊõúÊó•-Â§©Ê∞óÈõ®</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Kishibe Rohan wa Ugokanai Epis≈çdo Sebun Getsuy≈çbi - Tenkiame</i><sup class="t_nihongo_help noprint"><a href="/wiki/Help:Installing_Japanese_character_sets" title="Help:Installing Japanese character sets"><span class="t_nihongo_icon" style="color: #00e; font: bold 80% sans-serif; text-decoration: none; padding: 0 .1em;">?</span></a></sup>)</span> was published in <i>Weekly Sh≈çnen Jump</i> on December 4, 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Anime">Anime</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Anime">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Original_video_animations_and_film">Original video animations and film</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Original video animations and film">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure_(OVA)" title="JoJo's Bizarre Adventure (OVA)">JoJo's Bizarre Adventure (OVA)</a></div>
<p>Two <a href="/wiki/Original_Video_Animation" title="Original Video Animation" class="mw-redirect">OVA</a> adaptations of Part 3 Stardust Crusaders were produced by A.P.P.P. The original six-volume series begins during the middle of the arc and was released from November 19, 1993 to November 18, 1994. A seven-volume <a href="/wiki/Prequel" title="Prequel">prequel</a> series, titled <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure: Adventure</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Ç∏„Éß„Ç∏„Éß„ÅÆÂ•áÂ¶ô„Å™ÂÜíÈô∫ ADVENTURE</span>)</span>, was released from May 25, 2000 to October 25, 2002 and adapted the beginning of the arc. Super Techno Arts produced an English adaptation of both, the original series and the prequel series, releasing all thirteen episodes in North America as a six-volume DVD series between 2003 and 2005, with the episodes in order of its fictional chronology.</p>
<p><i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure: Phantom Blood</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Ç∏„Éß„Ç∏„Éß„ÅÆÂ•áÂ¶ô„Å™ÂÜíÈô∫ „Éï„Ç°„É≥„Éà„É†„Éñ„É©„ÉÉ„Éâ</span>)</span>, a feature film adaptation of the original first story arc, was released theatrically on February 17, 2007 in Japan. The film was produced to commemorate 25th anniversary of creator Hirohiko Araki's career as a manga artist. The theme song was "Voodoo Kingdom", a single by the group <a href="/wiki/Soul%27d_Out" title="Soul'd Out">Soul'd Out</a>. This film has yet to be released on any form of home video.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Television_series">Television series</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Television series">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure_episodes" title="List of JoJo's Bizarre Adventure episodes">List of JoJo's Bizarre Adventure episodes</a></div>
<p>At a July 5, 2012, press conference celebrating the 25th anniversary of the series and promoting an upcoming Hirohiko Araki art exhibition, Araki and his people announced that an anime adaptation was in production and would premiere in October 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-animePS3_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-animePS3-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup> A piece of promotional art was published in the August issue of <i>Ultra Jump</i>, depicting Jonathan Joestar and Dio Brando,<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup> suggesting that the anime will begin with Part 1 <i><a href="/wiki/Phantom_Blood" title="Phantom Blood">Phantom Blood</a></i>. The September issue of <i>Ultra Jump</i> announced the cast and staff; it is produced by <a href="/wiki/David_Production" title="David Production">David Production</a> and directed by Kenichi Suzuki, with <a href="/wiki/Kazuyuki_Okitsu" title="Kazuyuki Okitsu">Kazuyuki Okitsu</a> starring as Jonathan and <a href="/wiki/Takehito_Koyasu" title="Takehito Koyasu">Takehito Koyasu</a> voicing Dio.<sup id="cite_ref-animestaff_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-animestaff-30"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup> The 26-episode first season, which covers both the <i>Phantom Blood</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Battle_Tendency" title="Battle Tendency">Battle Tendency</a></i> arcs, aired on <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Metropolitan_Television" title="Tokyo Metropolitan Television">Tokyo Metropolitan Television</a> between October 5, 2012 and April 5, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-finalepisode_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-finalepisode-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>A teaser scene for Part 3 <i><a href="/wiki/Stardust_Crusaders" title="Stardust Crusaders">Stardust Crusaders</a></i> was shown following the credits of the final episode, and in the home video releases the final scene has a "To Be Continued" message.<sup id="cite_ref-finalepisode_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-finalepisode-32"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> On October 18, 2013, Warner Bros. Japan announced through an <a href="/wiki/Obi_strip" title="Obi strip" class="mw-redirect">obi strip</a> on <i>JoJolion</i> volume 5 and a special feature in <i>Weekly Sh≈çnen Jump</i> that a season covering <i>Stardust Crusaders</i> would premiere in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup> David Productions revealed that just like they used different art styles for <i>Phantom Blood</i> and <i>Battle Tendency</i>, they would be attempting a new art style with the <i>Stardust Crusaders</i> season. The series began airing in Japan on April 4, 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup> That same day, American-based website <a href="/wiki/Crunchyroll" title="Crunchyroll">Crunchyroll</a> began streaming the anime series for viewers outside Japan an hour after it aired in Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup> At the "Last Crusaders" event for <i>Stardust Crusaders</i>, an adaptation of <i><a href="/wiki/Diamond_is_Unbreakable" title="Diamond is Unbreakable" class="mw-redirect">Diamond is Unbreakable</a></i> was announced,<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup> and will premiere in April 2016.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Novels">Novels</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Novels">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Several <a href="/wiki/Light_novel" title="Light novel">light novels</a> based on the <i>JoJo</i> series have been written, each by a different author, but all including illustrations by Hirohiko Araki. The first, based on Part 3, was simply titled <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i>, released on November 4, 1993 and written by Mayori Sekijima and Hiroshi Yamaguchi.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>Le Bizzarre Avventure di GioGio II: Golden Heart/Golden Ring</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Ç∏„Éß„Ç∏„Éß„ÅÆÂ•áÂ¶ô„Å™ÂÜíÈô∫ II „Ç¥„Éº„É´„Éá„É≥„Éè„Éº„Éà/„Ç¥„Éº„É´„Éá„É≥„É™„É≥„Ç∞</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>JoJo no Kimy≈ç na B≈çken Ts≈´ G≈çruden HƒÅto/G≈çruden Ringu</i>)</span> written by Gichi ≈åtsuka and Miya Sh≈çtar≈ç, was released on May 28, 2001 and based on Part 5. Both of these novels received Italian translations and releases; the first in 2003,<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup> often with the added subtitle of <i>The Genesis of Universe</i>, and the second in 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In 2000, it was announced that <a href="/wiki/Otsuichi" title="Otsuichi">Otsuichi</a> would be writing a novel based on Part 4. The novel proved difficult to complete; in <i>Kono Mystery ga Sugoi!</i> 2004, Otsuichi claimed to have written over 2000 pages, but thrown them all out.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup> Intent on writing a novel that lived up to the manga, it took him until 2007 to complete <i>The Book: JoJo's Bizarre Adventure 4th Another Day</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In April 2011, it was announced that <a href="/wiki/Nisio_Isin" title="Nisio Isin">Nisio Isin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kouhei_Kadono" title="Kouhei Kadono">Kouhei Kadono</a>, and <a href="/wiki/%C5%8Ctar%C5%8D_Maij%C5%8D" title="≈åtar≈ç Maij≈ç">≈åtar≈ç Maij≈ç</a> were each writing novel adaptations of <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> in celebration of the series' 25th anniversary.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup> Kadono's, titled <i>Purple Haze Feedback</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">ÊÅ•Áü•„Çâ„Åö„ÅÆ„Éë„Éº„Éó„É´„Éò„Ç§„Ç∫</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Hajishirazu no PƒÅpuru Heizu</i>)</span>, was released on September 16, 2011 and is based on Part 5.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup> Isin's was released on December 16, 2011, based on Part 3 and titled <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure Over Heaven</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span>[</span>44<span>]</span></a></sup> Maij≈ç's novel, <i>Jorge Joestar</i>, was revealed in July and released on September 19, 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup> It tells the story of George Joestar II, son of Jonathan and father of Joseph, in his childhood growing up on <a href="/wiki/La_Palma" title="La Palma">La Palma</a> where he is known as "Jorge Joestar" as well as an alternate version living in Japan named "Joji Joestar" investigating mysteries behind the appearance of a moving island. It features characters from and inspired by nearly every part of <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Drama_CDs">Drama CDs</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Drama CDs">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>From 1992 to 1993, a <a href="/wiki/Radio_drama_in_Japan" title="Radio drama in Japan" class="mw-redirect">drama CD</a> adaptation of Part 3 was released in three volumes, titled <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure Volume 1: Meet Jotaro Kujo</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Ç∏„Éß„Ç∏„Éß„ÅÆÂ•áÂ¶ô„Å™ÂÜíÈô∫Á¨¨1Â∑ª Á©∫Êù°ÊâøÂ§™ÈÉéË¶ãÂèÇ„ÅÆÂ∑ª</span>)</span>, <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure Volume 2: The Death of Avdol</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Ç∏„Éß„Ç∏„Éß„ÅÆÂ•áÂ¶ô„Å™ÂÜíÈô∫Á¨¨2Â∑ª „Ç¢„É¥„Éâ„Ç•„É´Ê≠ª„Åô„ÅÆÂ∑ª</span>)</span> and <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure Volume 3: The World of Dio</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">„Ç∏„Éß„Ç∏„Éß„ÅÆÂ•áÂ¶ô„Å™ÂÜíÈô∫Á¨¨3Â∑ª DIO„ÅÆ‰∏ñÁïå„ÅÆÂ∑ª</span>)</span>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span>[</span>46<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span>[</span>47<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span>[</span>48<span>]</span></a></sup> They starred <a href="/wiki/Kiyoyuki_Yanada" title="Kiyoyuki Yanada">Kiyoyuki Yanada</a> as Jotaro, <a href="/wiki/Kenji_Utsumi" title="Kenji Utsumi">Kenji Utsumi</a> (volumes 1-2) and <a href="/wiki/Gor%C5%8D_Naya" title="Gor≈ç Naya">Gor≈ç Naya</a> (volume 3) as Joseph Joestar, <a href="/wiki/Akio_%C5%8Ctsuka" title="Akio ≈åtsuka">Akio ≈åtsuka</a> as Avdol, <a href="/wiki/Sh%C5%8D_Hayami" title="Sh≈ç Hayami">Sh≈ç Hayami</a> as Kakyoin, <a href="/wiki/Ken_Yamaguchi" title="Ken Yamaguchi">Ken Yamaguchi</a> as Polnareff, <a href="/wiki/Keiichi_Nanba" title="Keiichi Nanba">Keiichi Nanba</a> as Hol Horse, <a href="/wiki/Shigeru_Chiba" title="Shigeru Chiba">Shigeru Chiba</a> as J. Geil, and <a href="/wiki/Norio_Wakamoto" title="Norio Wakamoto">Norio Wakamoto</a> as Dio.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art_books">Art books</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Art books">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Araki has released multiple books containing original artwork he has produced for <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i>. <i>JoJo6251</i> was released in 1993 and features artwork, story details, and behind the scenes information for <i>Phantom Blood</i>, <i>Battle Tendency</i>, <i>Stardust Crusaders</i>, and <i>Diamond Is Unbreakable</i>. This was followed in 2000 by <i>JoJo A-Go! Go!</i> which features original artwork from <i>Vento Aureo</i> and <i>Stone Ocean</i>. In 2013, he released <i>JoJoveller</i>, a multimedia set that includes a book featuring original artwork for <i>Stone Ocean</i>, <i>Steel Ball Run</i>, and <i>JoJolion</i>; a book detailing the history of the publications; and a book detailing every Stand featured since <i>Stardust Crusaders</i>. The limited edition has two Blu-rays showing the 25th anniversary art exhibition in Tokyo and a behind-the-scenes look at Araki's creative process.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span>[</span>50<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Video_games">Video games</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Video games">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure_video_games" title="List of JoJo's Bizarre Adventure video games">List of JoJo's Bizarre Adventure video games</a></div>
<p>Several video games based on <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> have been created. A <a href="/wiki/Role-playing_video_game" title="Role-playing video game">role-playing video game</a> was released on the <a href="/wiki/Super_Famicom" title="Super Famicom" class="mw-redirect">Super Famicom</a> in 1993, and several <a href="/wiki/Fighting_game" title="Fighting game">fighting games</a> have been released, including <i><a href="/wiki/JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure:_All_Star_Battle" title="JoJo's Bizarre Adventure: All Star Battle">JoJo's Bizarre Adventure: All Star Battle</a></i> for the series' 25th anniversary.<sup id="cite_ref-animePS3_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-animePS3-28"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup> Characters from <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> have also been featured in various cross-over games with other characters from <i><a href="/wiki/Weekly_Sh%C5%8Dnen_Jump" title="Weekly Sh≈çnen Jump">Weekly Sh≈çnen Jump</a></i>.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Reception">Reception</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Reception">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p><i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> has over 95 million copies in print,<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span>[</span>51<span>]</span></a></sup> and is one of the best-selling <i>Weekly Sh≈çnen Jump</i> series of all-time.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span>[</span>52<span>]</span></a></sup> For the 10th anniversary of the <a href="/wiki/Japan_Media_Arts_Festival" title="Japan Media Arts Festival">Japan Media Arts Festival</a> in 2006, Japanese fans voted <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> second on a list of the Top 10 Manga of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span>[</span>53<span>]</span></a></sup> JoJo ranked 10th in a 2009 survey by <a href="/wiki/Oricon" title="Oricon">Oricon</a> on what manga series people want to see receive a live-action adaptation.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span>[</span>54<span>]</span></a></sup> The 2013 edition of <i>Kono Manga ga Sugoi!</i>, which surveys people in the manga and publishing industry, named <i>JoJolion</i> the 12th best manga series for male readers.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span>[</span>55<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>JoJolion</i> won the grand prize for manga at the 2013 Japan Media Arts Festival.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span>[</span>56<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The first volume of <i>JoJolion</i> was the second best-selling manga for its debut week, its second volume was number three and its third was number two.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span>[</span>57<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span>[</span>58<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span>[</span>59<span>]</span></a></sup> All three volumes were some of the best-selling manga of 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span>[</span>60<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span>[</span>61<span>]</span></a></sup> All three volumes of Viz Media's release of <i>Phantom Blood</i> and the first volume of <i>Battle Tendency</i> reached the top two positions on <a href="/wiki/List_of_The_New_York_Times_Manga_Best_Sellers" title="List of The New York Times Manga Best Sellers"><i>The New York Times</i> Manga Best Seller list</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span>[</span>62<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span>[</span>63<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span>[</span>64<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span>[</span>65<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/IGN" title="IGN">IGN</a> named the series a "must read", declaring the artwork of "a standard virtually unseen in most manga produced today".<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span>[</span>66<span>]</span></a></sup> Rebecca Silverman of <a href="/wiki/Anime_News_Network" title="Anime News Network">Anime News Network</a> wrote that <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> "combines a fighting story with a solid emotional background, and will absolutely put hair on your chest." She called Dio an excellent villain that the readers can enjoy hating. However, she criticized the anatomy of characters, saying "bodies are often twisted into impossible positions."<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span>[</span>67<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Otaku_USA" title="Otaku USA">Otaku USA</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s Joseph Luster called the series "fun as hell" and noted how the beginning is not filled with action like most <i>Weekly Sh≈çnen Jump</i> series, but instead has the tension of horror and thriller films.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span>[</span>68<span>]</span></a></sup> Heidi Kemps, also of <i>Otaku USA</i>, was mostly positive in her review of <i>Rohan at the Louvre</i>, praising the art for being drawn in full-color by hand, although noted that readers new to <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> might not fully understand the ending due to there being only a brief explanation of Rohan's Stand power.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span>[</span>69<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The first set of OVAs was given three out of five stars by Eric Gaede of THEM Anime Reviews. He praised the fight scenes as more believable than those from other series such as <i><a href="/wiki/Dragon_Ball" title="Dragon Ball">Dragon Ball</a></i> and the characters' personalities, although felt the villains resorted to clich√©s when they are about to be defeated. However, he called the story "disjointed" and the animation "drab and colorless".<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span>[</span>70<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> TV anime was named one of the best of 2012 by <i>Otaku USA</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71"><span>[</span>71<span>]</span></a></sup> It was added to the list by Joseph Luster, however, in his review he cited David Production having a small budget for several of his problems with the series, stating some portions of the animation are a "butt hair above motion comic standards," but that it usually makes up for it in "sheer style."<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span>[</span>72<span>]</span></a></sup> Michael Toole of Anime News Network had similar views, writing that the show's good writing, art direction, and pacing were "sometimes obscured by grade-Z animation."<sup id="cite_ref-Toole_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Toole-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> At the 2013 <a href="/wiki/CEDEC_Awards" title="CEDEC Awards">CEDEC Awards</a>, the anime's opening sequence won in the Visual Arts division.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span>[</span>73<span>]</span></a></sup> Several critics have credited the success of the anime adaptation for bringing about a surge of popularity for the <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> franchise amongst Western audiences.<sup id="cite_ref-Toole_6-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Toole-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74"><span>[</span>74<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Controversy">Controversy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Controversy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In May 2008, both Shueisha and studio A.P.P.P. halted manga/OVA shipments of <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> after a complaint had been launched against them from <a href="/wiki/Egyptians" title="Egyptians">Egyptian</a> <a href="/wiki/Islamic_fundamentalism" title="Islamic fundamentalism">Islamic fundamentalists</a>, after noticing a scene in the OVAs that has the villain, Dio Brando, reading a book depicting pages from the <a href="/wiki/Qur%27an" title="Qur'an" class="mw-redirect">Qur'an</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1000manga_15-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1000manga-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75"><span>[</span>75<span>]</span></a></sup> This recall affected the English-language releases as well, causing Viz Media and Shueisha to cease publication for a year. Even though the manga did not feature that specific scene, Shueisha had Araki redraw scenes that depicted characters fighting on top of, and destroying, mosques for later printings of the series.<sup id="cite_ref-1000manga_15-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1000manga-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup> Viz resumed publication a year later, with the eleventh volume being published on April 7, 2009. <a href="/wiki/Jason_Thompson_(writer)" title="Jason Thompson (writer)">Jason Thompson</a> later included Shueisha's changes to the manga in the list of "The Greatest Censorship Fails" in manga.<sup id="cite_ref-censorship2_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-censorship2-76"><span>[</span>76<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy_and_collaborations">Legacy and collaborations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Legacy and collaborations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The September 2007 issue of <i><a href="/wiki/Cell_(journal)" title="Cell (journal)">Cell</a></i> had a cover drawn by Hirohiko Araki with a <a href="/wiki/Ligase" title="Ligase">ligase</a> represented as a <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> Stand.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span>[</span>77<span>]</span></a></sup> He also contributed artwork towards the restoration of <a href="/wiki/Ch%C5%ABson-ji" title="Ch≈´son-ji">Ch≈´son-ji</a> following the <a href="/wiki/2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami" title="2011 T≈çhoku earthquake and tsunami">2011 T≈çhoku earthquake and tsunami</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span>[</span>78<span>]</span></a></sup> Araki contributed <i>JoJo</i>-inspired art for <a href="/wiki/Sayuri_Ishikawa" title="Sayuri Ishikawa">Sayuri Ishikawa</a>'s 2012 album <i>X -Cross-</i>, where she performs one of the series' iconic poses and is drawn wearing jewelry from the manga.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span>[</span>79<span>]</span></a></sup> <i>JoJo</i>-style artwork has also been produced for other literature, such as for a 2008 collection featuring <a href="/wiki/Yasunari_Kawabata" title="Yasunari Kawabata">Yasunari Kawabata</a>'s short story "<a href="/wiki/The_Dancing_Girl_of_Izu" title="The Dancing Girl of Izu">The Dancing Girl of Izu</a>"<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span>[</span>80<span>]</span></a></sup> and a 2012 reprint of <a href="/wiki/Tamaki_Sait%C5%8D" title="Tamaki Sait≈ç">Tamaki Sait≈ç</a>'s <i>Lacan for Surviving</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81"><span>[</span>81<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>In 2009, Araki's artwork for <i>JoJo's Bizarre Adventure</i> was one of five artists featured in <a href="/wiki/The_Louvre" title="The Louvre" class="mw-redirect">the Louvre</a>'s <i>Le Louvre invite la bande dessin√©e</i> ("The Louvre Invites Comic-Strip Art") exhibition. To commemorate this honor, he wrote <i>Rohan au Louvre</i> <span style="font-weight: normal">(<span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">Â≤∏Ëæ∫Èú≤‰º¥ „É´„Éº„É¥„É´„Å∏Ë°å„Åè</span><span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">,</span> <i>Kishibe Rohan R≈´vuru e Iku</i>)</span>, a 123-page full color story starring Rohan Kishibe visiting the Louvre and discovering a cursed painting tied to his family.<sup id="cite_ref-Louvre_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Louvre-82"><span>[</span>82<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Nat_Louvre_1_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nat_Louvre_1-83"><span>[</span>83<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Nat_Louvre_2_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nat_Louvre_2-84"><span>[</span>84<span>]</span></a></sup> The following year it was published in France and ran in <i>Ultra Jump</i>, and in February 2012 was translated and released in North America by <a href="/wiki/NBM_Publishing" title="NBM Publishing">NBM Publishing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span>[</span>85<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Gucci">Gucci</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=JoJo%27s_Bizarre_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Gucci">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
